quizzes.question: How many numbers does the range (5...7) contain?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Ranges[/h1]

A [b]range [/b]represents a sequence. 0 to 10, 56 to 82, and a to z are all examples of ranges.
Ruby has special operators to create ranges with ease.
These are the ''[b]..[/b]'' and ''[b]...[/b]'' range operators. The two-dot form creates an inclusive range, while the three-dot form creates a range that excludes the specified high value.
[b]For example:[/b][code format="rb" codeId="1005"]a = (1..7).to_a
puts a # [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7]

b = (79...82).to_a
puts b # [79, 80, 81]

c = ("a".."d").to_a
puts c # [a, b, c, d][/code]
[note]The [b]to_a [/b]method is used to convert a range to an array, so we can output it. 
You will learn more about arrays in the coming lessons.[/note]

quizzes.question:
What is the output of this code?
x = 8
case x
when 0...8
  puts "1"
else
  puts "2"
end
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Ranges[/h1]

Ranges can be used in [b]case [/b]statements for [b]when [/b]values.
[b]For example:[/b] [code format="rb" codeId="1006"]age = 42

case age
when 0..14
  puts "Child"
when 15..24
  puts "Youth"
when 25..64
  puts "Adult"
else
  puts "Senior"
end[/code]
[note]Ranges are also useful in [b]for [/b]loops. You will learn about them in the coming lesson.[/note]
